name: French Onion Soup
description: The rich, caramelized onions and beef broth need a wine with some acidity to cut through, but enough fruit to complement the sweetness.

name: Escargots à la Bourguignonne
description: Garlic and parsley butter loves the high acidity of a Chablis or the earthy notes of a light Pinot Noir.

name: Steak Frites with Béarnaise
description: A classic bistro pairing. The tannins in the Bordeaux cut through the fatty steak and rich Béarnaise sauce.

name: Confit de Canard
description: Rich duck confit requires a rustic red with good structure to balance the salt and fat.

name: Crème Brûlée
description: A classic sweet pairing; the honeyed notes of Sauternes mirror the caramelized sugar crust.

name: Burrata with Parma Ham
description: The creaminess of the burrata and saltiness of the ham are refreshed by the bubbles and acidity of Prosecco.

name: Lobster Linguine
description: A rich seafood pasta needs a white wine with body and texture, or a crisp Gavi to cleanse the palate.

name: Wild Boar Pappardelle
description: Gamey ragu is the perfect match for the savory, herbal notes and acidity of a Chianti.

name: Tiramisu
description: Coffee and cocoa flavors pair beautifully with the nuttiness of an aged Vin Santo or Marsala.

name: Pandan Chicken
description: The aromatic spices and slight sweetness of the chicken wrapper are elevated by an aromatic white wine.

name: Rendang Daging (Beef Rendang)
description: This intensely spiced coconut beef curry needs a fruit-forward red with low tannins to avoid accentuating the heat.

name: Mango Sticky Rice
description: The tropical fruit and creamy rice find a perfect partner in a sweet, floral Moscato.

name: Grilled Halloumi
description: Salty cheese needs a high-acid wine to cut through it. Assyrtiko from Santorini is a thematic and structural fit.

name: Mixed Grill Platter
description: Charcoal-grilled meats pair well with the smoky, vanilla notes of a barrel-aged Rioja.

name: Baklava
description: Ideally paired with a very sweet wine to match the intense sugar syrup and nuts of the pastry.

name: Crispy Squid
description: Fried seafood demands a bone-dry, zesty white wine to act as a squeeze of lemon.

name: Coppa Club Burger
description: A juicy burger works best with a medium-to-full bodied red that has plenty of fruit and moderate tannin.

name: Sticky Toffee Pudding
description: The caramel and date flavors are intensified by the dried fruit and nut notes of a Tawny Port.

name: Prawn Toast
description: Fried appetizers like prawn toast love sparkling wine to cut through the oil.

name: Crispy Chilli Beef
description: The sweetness and spice of this dish pair well with an off-dry Riesling or a jammy Zinfandel.

name: Pappardelle with 8-hour Beef Shin Ragu
description: A rich, slow-cooked beef ragu needs a wine with high acidity and tannins like Barolo.

name: Pani Puri
description: A fresh, zesty appetiser that needs a crisp, refreshing wine.

name: Butter Chicken
description: The creamy tomato sauce is complemented by the body and slight sweetness of an oaked Chardonnay.

name: Orkney Scallop with Cauliflower
description: Delicate scallops and nutty cauliflower require a refined, complex white wine.

name: Confit Duck Leg
description: Duck and Pinot Noir is a match made in heaven, balancing fat and acidity.

name: Tonkotsu Ramen
description: The rich pork broth pairs classically with a clean, dry Sake or a crisp Lager.

name: Peking Duck
description: The crispy skin and hoisin sauce pair wonderfully with the fruitiness of Pinot Noir.

name: Jamón Ibérico
description: The salty, nutty fat of the ham is perfectly cleansed by the dry, saline bite of Fino Sherry.

name: Padrón Peppers
description: Green, slightly bitter vegetal notes work best with a fresh, citrusy white wine.

name: Massaman Lamb Shank
description: The rich, sweet spices of Massaman curry pair well with the spice and fruit of a Syrah.

name: Korean Fried Chicken
description: Fried, spicy chicken needs a cutting beverage like Soju or a sweet Riesling.

name: Chuletón (Ribeye Steak)
description: A big, fatty steak needs a bold Spanish red with structure and tannin.

name: Jollof Rice with Chicken
description: The heat and tomato base of Jollof rice work well with a fruity Rosé or Zinfandel.

name: Argentinian Beef Cuts
description: Argentinian beef was born to be paired with Malbec.

name: Pie & Mash
description: Traditional East End food deserves a traditional British ale.

name: Black Cod
description: The rich, buttery miso glaze pairs perfectly with a premium Sake or creamy Chardonnay.

name: French Onion Soup
description: A rustic bistro classic that pairs well with a light red or even a dry cider.

name: Soufflé
description: A light, effervescent pairing.

name: Jamón Ibérico de Bellota
description: Top-tier ham deserves a complex, aged Cava or a nutty Amontillado.

name: Orecchiette with Cime di Rapa
description: A classic Puglian dish pairs best with the local red wines of the region.

name: Whole Grilled Dover Sole
description: A noble fish served simply needs a noble white wine with texture.

name: Beef Brisket
description: Smoky BBQ brisket loves the caramel notes of specific Zinfandels or a straight Bourbon.

name: Hock Terrine
description: The textural terrine and sharp pickles work well with the acidity of Chenin Blanc.

name: Shepherd’s Pie
description: Comfort food elevated; a classic red Bordeaux (Claret) is the traditional choice.

name: Scallop with Pumpkin and Hazelnut
description: Complex, earthy flavors from the pumpkin and hazelnut allow for an adventurous pairing like Orange wine.

name: South African Beef Cuts
description: When eating South African beef, drink South African wine like the indigenous Pinototage.

name: Fruits de Mer Platter
description: Shellfish platters require high-acid, saline wines like Muscadet from the Loire Valley.

name: Pâté en croûte
description: Avoid tannin: metallic clash.

name: Escargot croquette
description: Avoid oak.

name: Mackerel
description: Avoid aromatic whites.

name: Vol-au-vent
description: Avoid high alcohol.

name: Artichoke
description: Avoid tannin entirely.

name: Cuttlefish ink
description: Avoid Sauvignon Blanc.

name: White asparagus
description: Avoid sweetness.

name: Girolles
description: Avoid fruit bombs.

name: Chateaubriand
description: Avoid jammy styles.

name: Roast chicken
description: Avoid oak.

name: Bar en croûte
description: Avoid red wine.

name: Lamb shoulder
description: Avoid overripe versions.

name: Pigeon pithivier
description: Avoid heavy extraction.

name: Dulcey chocolate
description: Rich chocolate needs a fortified wine like Banyuls.

name: Fruit tarts
description: Fresh fruit tarts pair beautifully with the floral sweetness of Moscato.

name: Mont Blanc
description: Light pour.
